content.question: Light of wavelength <math alttext="lambda" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>λ</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> that delivers energy at a rate <math alttext="R" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>R</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> will not eject electrons from a certain metal. Increasing the rate of energy delivery without changing the wavelength has no effect. Light of wavelength <math alttext="the fraction lambda over 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>λ</mi><mo>/</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> that delivers energy at a rate <math alttext="R" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>R</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> does cause electrons to be ejected from the metal. Which of the following claims can be made based on this result?

choices.label: Light is behaving as a wave in this case.
Light is behaving as a particle in this case.
Light is behaving as both a particle and a wave in this case.
This experiment provides no information on the nature of light.

content.answer: Light is behaving as a particle in this case.

skill.text: 3.B: Apply an appropriate law, definition, theoretical relationship, or model to make a claim.
